facts.text: Appellant Purushottamdas Dalmia was one of the partners of the firm Laxminarayan Gourishankar with head office at Gaya and branch at 19, Sambhu Mallick Lane, Calcutta.
On April 26, 1952, the appellant applied for a licence for importing rupees one crore worth of art silk yarn.
On May 2, 1952, the Joint Chief Controller of Imports, Calcutta, issued a provisional licence which was to be confirmed within two months.
The provisional licence was not confirmed within two months; appellant was informed of refusal to confirm.
Appellant's appeal against refusal dismissed in September 1952; provisional licences returned.
Letter dated September 26, 1952 from Joint Chief Controller communicating dismissal of appeal and return of licence.
Letter dated September 29, 1952 from Chief Controller of Imports, New Delhi, advising to contact Joint Chief Controller for reconsideration.
Appellant applied on October 7, 1952 for return of correspondence, returned on October 9, 1952.
On March 31, 1953, appellant wrote to Chief Controller expressing grievance and requesting sympathetic decision.
Chief Controller's letter dated April 20, 1953 informed refusal to revise, but gave wrong number 16 instead of 19.
Appellant states he did not receive the April 20, 1953 letter.
In August 1953, appellant met Kalyanam at Calcutta; Kalyanam said he could get licence validated via acquaintance Rajan at Delhi.
Appellant and Kalyanam went to Delhi in August 1953, visited Rajan; appellant gave file containing licences to Kalyanam who passed to Rajan.
Two or three days later, Kalyanam returned licences containing forged endorsements to appellant: confirmation purported July 2, 1952; re-validation purported April 25, 1953 till May 2, 1954.
Orders placed on basis of re-validated licence; goods arrived, attempt to clear at Madras; clearing office suspected endorsements, confirmed forgery, referred to police.
Appellant and Kalyanam committed to Calcutta High Court for trial; eight charges framed, including conspiracy under s.120B r/w s.471 IPC and others under s.471 r/w s.466 IPC.
Jury trial: guilty verdict against appellant on conspiracy under s.120B r/w s.471 IPC, and charges 4 and 7 (using forged documents); not guilty on others.
Kalyanam convicted on various charges but did not appeal.
Calcutta High Court Single Judge convicted appellant; appeal summarily dismissed May 16, 1958; special leave appeal to Supreme Court.
It is not disputed that forgeries were committed in documents Exts. 5 and 6.

legal_issues.text: Whether Calcutta High Court had jurisdiction to try offences under s.471 r/w s.466 IPC committed at Madras in pursuance of conspiracy triable at Calcutta.
Whether charging alternative conspiracies is invalid.

Whether the trial judge misdirected the jury on knowledge of forgery from ante-dating, effect of ante-dating even if signed by proper officer, receipt of April 20, 1953 letter, and expression of strong opinions.

petitioner_arguments.text: Offences of using forged documents under s.471 r/w s.466 IPC committed at Madras; Calcutta courts had no jurisdiction per s.177 CrPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.177 CrPC; Jiban Banerjee v. State

petitioner_arguments.text: Alternative conspiracies cannot be charged as they must result from different agreements.

Judge misdirected jury: (a) accused must know re-validation forgery from ante-dated confirmation; (b) ante-dated endorsement by proper officer still forgery; (c) April 20 letter must have reached appellant; (d) strong opinions affected jury.

court_reasoning.text: Calcutta High Court had jurisdiction to try overt acts (using forged documents at Madras) in pursuance of conspiracy triable there, as part of same transaction; desirable for single trial; overrules Jiban Banerjee v. State; ss.235, 239 CrPC enable joint trial irrespective of territorial jurisdiction for offences in course of same transaction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions of CrPC ss.235,239 allow trial of conspiracy and overt acts together even if some acts outside jurisdiction; territorial jurisdiction matter of convenience, not root of jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Charge not alternative conspiracies but single conspiracy to commit offences punishable with 2+ years RI, described in alternative (forgery or use as genuine); justified by s.236 CrPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expression 'and/or' covers uncertainty whether conspiracy included forgery or just use knowing forged.

court_reasoning.text: No misdirection: judge expressed opinions but told jury not bound, to decide facts; ante-dating makes false document even if signed properly; knowledge of ante-dating implies knowledge of forgery; letter likely reached despite address error; appellant's inaction consistent with receipt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jury free to form own conclusions; propositions of law correct.

holdings.text: Court trying criminal conspiracy has jurisdiction to try overt acts in pursuance thereof committed outside its territorial jurisdiction if part of same transaction, per ss.235,239 CrPC.
Single conspiracy charge in alternative form valid under s.236 CrPC where nature of contemplated offences uncertain.
No misdirection in summing up to jury.

precedents_cited.relevance: Supported no jurisdiction for overt acts outside territory; court disagrees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pritam Singh v. The State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Risk of inconsistent findings if separate trials.

precedents_cited.case_name: Assistant Sessions Judge, North Arcot v. Ramaswami Asari
precedents_cited.relevance: ss.177-189 enlarge trial sites, minimize technical pleas.
Conspiracy and overt act triable where either occurred per s.180 CrPC.
Murders in adjacent districts should be tried together under s.234 CrPC.
Held no jurisdiction under s.239 without territorial jurisdiction for abetment.
Similar to Sachidanandam; Calcutta HC view disapproved.

precedents_cited.case_name: Babulal Choukhani v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Conspiracy and overt acts in course of same transaction; s.239(d) no limit on offences.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges for conspiracy, forgery, using forged document as genuine, abetment.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction, joint trials for same transaction/conspiracy/overt acts; territorial jurisdiction subordinate.

outcome.summary: Appeal against conviction and sentence by Calcutta High Court dismissed; all contentions rejected, upholding jurisdiction, validity of charge, and absence of misdirection.

key_quotes.text: The desirability of the trial, together, of an offence of criminal conspiracy and of all the overt acts committed in pursuance of it, is obvious.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies joint trial despite territorial limits.

key_quotes.text: Territorial jurisdiction is provided just as a matter of convenience, keeping in mind the administrative point of view with respect to the work of a particular Court, the convenience of the accused... and the convenience of the witnesses.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We therefore hold that the Calcutta Court had jurisdiction to try the appellant of the offences under s.471 read with s.466, Indian Penal Code, even though those offences... were committed at Madras.
key_quotes.speaker: court
